ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much from this class about topics I was actually interested in. It provided a great overview of all aspects of East Asian media, and I'm now able to view media and consider the information and context this class has provided me.
Post-modern therories in culture analysis
We learned how to critically analyze East Asian media portrayals and how they can help bolster national narratives. We were able to compare differences between China, Korea, and Japan.

Important media vocabulary.
How different East Asian countries' social issues appear in and shape media.
Learned a lot about media studies focusing on east Asia. Helped us build the language to discuss film, TV, video games, and culture through a critical lens.
I gained more knowledge of how to analyze media and better understanding of the contemporary culture and politics of East Asia.

International relations of East Asia especially through the lens of screen culture, about screen culture and other pop culture phenomena that rely on media and other forms of technology. Some elements of messages and methods in film and media.

this course allowed me to further engage and understand various aspects of east asian screen culture, which gave me more context when watching any east asian films. i learned a good deal of both history and politics of east asia, and they were both well balanced to a great amount of exposure to popular and revolutionary east asian films

I learned about the history of certain screen cultures commonly found in East Asia and the importance of tracing back the origins. I also improved in writing papers that emphasize class readings and making specific arguments.
What it means to consume different types of East Asian media, and how said media influences society

I learned how to critically think about cinema and other works of media. I learned about East Asian history as well and the history of cinema in Korea/Japan/China. As someone who consumes a lot of East Asian content such as anime, K-Pop, and K-Dramas, this was very insightful and has allowed me to approach these forms of media with a more educated perspective.
I learned a lot about the politics of modern East Asian history (particularly China, Japan, and Korea) and how it correlates to the screen culture of those countries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths- By far the most interesting class I've taken at Yale
Weaknesses- Very open-ended prompts for all the papers- possible a strength though?

Strength: wide range of materials and theories covered
Weakness: every student comes with their own interests and consumption in East Asian screen content. I feel like there could be more dialogue to unpack our experience and feelings when watching the films and TV shows. It might be more fun if it is a small seminar with more focused topics.

Strengths: Very well organized with clearly communicated expectations, good balance between lecture and student discussion, readings were specifically discussed in weekly lectures, and assignments were beneficial towards our learning. Lectures were great at providing a general history of time periods in which specific films were created so we could understand the social and political context. I appreciated the variety in films we watched--most of the films were very engaging and directly related to the weekly readings.  Lastly, I really liked how the memorandums and paper topics were left open ended so that we could explore the topics we found most interesting. 

Weaknesses: This course was sometimes not very approachable for someone like myself who did not grow up in an East Asian household. Sometimes it was assumed we had prior background information of a TV show or band, or we were asked to do a discussion post about East Asian media we consumed as a child. Next time it may be good to offer an alternative discussion prompt for those who are having their first exposure to East Asian media in this class.

Strengths included a vibrant and diversified curriculum, with a lot of material drawn from films, TV, articles, essays, music videos, and more. 
Weakness was that the guidelines for the essays and projects were at times elusive. It would have been nice to be able to read example essays. Sometimes the objective of the assignments wasn't clear until after it was graded and we received our score.
Strengths are the great lectures and very fair assignment structure. Weaknesses are the extended discussion class sections.

Strengths: The material is entertaining and informational.
Weaknesses: Sometimes it's information overload so it's not clear what to focus on. There's an obvious advantage to those who know more about East Asian screen culture, but it should be emphasized more that a background in East Asian screen culture is necessary for completing assignments.

strengths: very engaging, really enjoyed the room for student participation and discussion during classes
weaknesses: sometimes lecture classes would get a little too detailed and hard to follow, pace was a bit too fast to take in everything at once

The strengths include the support from the professor and the TFs, the comfortable and safe environment created during each class that made it easier to share my thoughts and opinions, and the valuable feedback provided by my TF.
It the lecture one day and discussion the second day format worked well for me. It was quite enjoyable

Strengths: Very interesting content, professor was very passionate and well-informed on topic, professor was very open to feedback and would make changes based on feedback, interesting assignments that allowed students to pursue research areas that interested them the most, manageable workload
Weaknesses: Some of the lectures were not as interesting as others

The strengths are the course's format and the balance between lecture and student interaction, as well as the presentation of interesting topics. The weaknesses are readings can sometimes be uninteresting and heavy on intellectual jargon. Additionally, there were times when the feedback on assignments was lackluster and grading was not explained well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES! If you're interested in the topic, I would most definitely recommend. The workload was more than I expected though.
Pretty good intro course for East Asian screen culture and post-modern theories

Yes! The course is well designed to increase your understanding of East Asian society as a whole (socially, politically, etc) by analyzing a wide variety of media portrayals across three main countries. Professor Li and the TA's were super approachable and great at providing timely feedback for each assignment. Great way to get your first exposure to many different kinds of East Asian media!
Yes, especially if you are interested in East Asian social issues and different forms of media.
Yes! I think Yale, and the F&M studies department needs more area studies, media-centered course offerings. Prof Li is incredibly knowledgeable and approachable. I feel like I learned a lot.
Yes. The course material is very interesting and Professor Li is knowledgeable and engaging.
Yes, it's very interesting to learn about, but does require past knowledge of East Asian screen culture.

yes, i loved this course, it was super interesting and actually fun; all of the projects and most of homework assignments were ones i actually looked forward to completing, very engaging class allowing lots of freedom for work
Yes! It is a wonderful humanities class that dives into East Asian screen culture. The professor and the TFs are amazing and will support you and help you in any and all ways they can.

Yes! It you enjoy East Asian media and want to get a more academic understanding of it, I recommend. Or if you want to learn more about East Asian film and media in general. I got some great movie and tv show recommendations.
Yes if you like East Asian screen culture. It was very interesting!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is friendly to people who are interested in east asian history and to people that are interested in film, and especially to those who are interested in both.
